awd_titl_txt: Restoration of Scientific Capabilities at the Arecibo Observatory after the impact of Hurricane Maria
awd_abstract_narration:
This project is to restore the Arecibo Observatory (AO) to full operating status after the damage it incurred from Hurricane Maria in September 2017. The Arecibo Observatory uniquely contributes to a wide variety of sciences including astronomy, planetary science, ionospheric physics, and the study and prediction of space weather. Its powerful antenna has capabilities for particular measurements unmatched anywhere in the world. The Arecibo Observatory is a leading education and public outreach center. It is a beacon of science education in Puerto Rico, attracting tens of thousands of school children and tourists annually. This award will enable Arecibo to restore its full complement of science capabilities and education and public outreach efforts.   

This award to the University of Central Florida (UCF) in cooperation with Yang Enterprises, Inc. (YEI) is for repairs comprising fourteen distinct projects, prioritized by criticality for both structural integrity and the importance to scientific observations.  These projects include: the replacement of a compromised steel suspension cable that is one of three cables supporting the approximately 900-ton steel platform suspended more than 400 feet above the 305-meter primary reflector surface, which houses the receivers and other associated equipment; calibration of the primary reflector surface panels; alignment of the Gregorian reflector; replacement of the damaged 430 MHz line feed; restoration to full functionality of the telescope pointing control and data taking systems; along with several other smaller projects.  These systems are critical to ensuring that the Arecibo Observatory has been restored to world-class operating status with resilient systems in case of another hurricane by capitalizing on modern technologies to optimize scientific performance.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
• Site radio frequency interferences (RFI) monitoring: A standard RFI station was designed and developed to replace equipment damaged during the hurricane. All documentation was prepared for their future use as part of a network to monitor RFI at the Arecibo site.
  • Erosion mitigation: Upon consulting with a local environmental agency, gabions were developed, assembled, and installed around the main telescope tie down blocks in order to secure them after flooding and prevent future weather erosion.
  • 12m antenna: The Arecibo 12m antenna was repaired and enhanced with a cryogenic receiver. On-sky measurements showed that the telescope performance in S-band frequencies was fantastic and acceptable in X-Band. The 12m telescope with the new receiver was used for shared risk observations in July and up to August 8th, 2024. Observations included RRL survey toward Cygnus X region, a CH survey of the galactic center region, an HCCCN survey toward HII regions, pulsar monitoring, searches for stellar flares, as well as solar imaging.
  • Site security cameras: 39 cameras were installed across the site providing operation within acceptable RFI limitations, cameras were connected to the central system, and security guards were trained for using the network.
  • Lidar laboratory: The Lidar laboratory roof was repaired to provide proper weather protection for all the laser, computer, and other equipment it hosts. Lasers that were damaged by the chiller failure during Hurricane Maria were replaced.
  • Storage and transmitters laboratory: The damaged modular storage unit hosting klystrons, power components, and other electronics was replaced by a new building, which is humidity and temperature controlled.
